member.name: T:VoiceElements.Client.RoutableResource
member.summary: Represents any resource that can be routed to aother resource.

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.RoutableResource.RouteFull(VoiceElements.Client.RoutableResource)
member.summary: Completes a full route between two resources. Both channels then list to each other.
member.param: Routable Resource This is the Routable Resource to which you would like to route. Since you are calling this as a method on a resource, thst provides the first resource.
member.remarks:
The RouteFull method routes the transmit timeslots of both resources together. This will allow a routable resource to listen to another resource. It will also allow the other resource to listen to the first resource. This is ideal for calling card applications.
Routing Resources
Routing resources is very powerful. It allows a resource to listen to another. If, for example you wanted to create a call center application, you would need to route the inbound caller in such a way that the call center agent would be able to speak to the caller. The full route allows you to do just this.
RouteFull vs Route Half
A full route allows both parties to listen to each other, while a Route Half will allow one party to listen to the other.

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.TelephonyServer.RegisterDNIS
member.summary: Registers all inbound DNIS's. The VE Server will then send all inbound calls to this application, raising new call events.
member.remarks:
Once DNIS's have been registered, the Telephony Server will take any inbound calls received for that exact DNIS string and raise a New Call event. When that event is received, it is recommended you create a separate class to run a script that comprises your voice interface. The script will execute Plays, Get Responses from callers and any other functions of your application.
You may need to contact your voice carrier or run some test calls to determine the exact length and content of the DNIS's coming into your system if you intend to register specific ones.
Retrieving the DNIS in Your Code
To retreive the DNIS for use in your application any time suring the lifetime of the call raised by the event, use the Channel Resource DNIS property to your user account on the server.
There are two ways to deploy your application.
Using Inventive Labs Telephony Bank
When using the Inventive Labs Telephony Bank or "Cloud", this method will only register the DNIS's which have been assigned to your user account on the server.
Using Your Dedicated Server
When using your own dedicated Voice Elements Server, this method will result in all inbound DNIS's being routed to the client application that registers.

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.TelephonyServer.RegisterDNIS(System.String)
member.summary: Registers a specific inbound DNIS. The VE Server will then send all inbound calls for that DNIS to this application, raising new call events.
member.param: This is an exact string of the DNIS you would like to register. You may need to contact your voice carrier or run some test calls to determine the exact length and content of the DNIS's coming into your system to ensure you register them correctly.
member.remarks:
Once DNIS's have been registered, the Telephony Server will take any inbound calls received for that exact DNIS string and raise a New Call event. When that event is received, it is recommended you create a separate class to run a script that comprises your voice interface. The script will execute Plays, Get Responses from callers and any other functions of your application.
Retrieving the DNIS in Your Code
To retreive the DNIS for use in your application any time suring the lifetime of the call raised by the event, use the Channel Resource DNIS property to your user account on the server.
There are two ways to deploy your application.
Using Inventive Labs Telephony Bank
When using the Inventive Labs Telephony Bank or "Cloud", this method will only register the DNIS's which have been assigned to your user account on the server.
Using Your Dedicated Server
When using your own dedicated Voice Elements Server, this method will result in all inbound DNIS's being routed to the client application that registers.

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.TelephonyServer.RegisterDNIS(System.String[])
member.summary: Registers an array of specific DNIS's. The VE Server will then send all inbound calls for every DNIS in the array to this application, raising new call events.
member.param: This is an array of exact strings of the DNIS's you would like to register. You may need to contact your voice carrier or run some test calls to determine the exact length and content of the DNIS's coming into your system to ensure you register them correctly.
member.remarks:
Once DNIS's have been registered, the Telephony Server will take any inbound calls received for any exact DNIS string in the array passed and raise a New Call event. When that event is received, it is recommended you create a separate class to run a script that comprises your voice interface. The script will execute Plays, Get Responses from callers and any other functions of your application.
Retrieving the DNIS in Your Code
To retreive the DNIS for use in your application any time suring the lifetime of the call raised by the event, use the Channel Resource DNIS property to your user account on the server.
There are two ways to deploy your application.
Using Inventive Labs Telephony Bank
When using the Inventive Labs Telephony Bank or "Cloud", this method will only register the DNIS's which have been assigned to your user account on the server.
Using Your Dedicated Server
When using your own dedicated Voice Elements Server, this method will result in all inbound DNIS's being routed to the client application that registers.

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.TelephonyServer.TtsToFile(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Converts the specified text string into speech and saves it as the designated file.
member.param:
String
Description: This is the text that the TTS engine will speak into the output file.
Note: You can use parameters and tags to change the way the engine speaks and also specify currency, dates, etc. For more information on configuring TTS by adding paramters to this string, see Text-to-Speech Tips and Topics from Inventive Labs support.

String of Path and File Name
This specifies the file for the wave output. See remarks below about file format.
member.exception: Thrown when the file or text string are null or a file access exception occurs.
member.remarks:
Output File Format
The output file will usually be formatted as 8 kHz 8 bit mu-law wave file. Voice Elements uses native G.711 which determines the format. This is the codec used at the transport level for SIP, T1's and PRI's. This allows files to be played without any conversion overhead.
Default Voice
This method has an additional overload allowing the use of any available specific TTS voice. In this case, since no voice is specified, Voice Elements will use the voice specified in the Name setting of the [TTS] section of the CTI32.ini settings file in the root application directory of the Voice Elements server. For more information on TTS settings on the server, see
TTS Settings on Voice Elements Server from Inventive Labs support.
member.seealso: TTS Settings on Voice Elements Server

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.TelephonyServer.TtsToFile(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Converts the specified text string into speech and saves it as the designated file using the voice designated in the third parameter.
member.param:
String
Description: This is the text that the TTS engine will speak into the output file.
Note: You can use parameters and tags to change the way the engine speaks and also specify currency, dates, etc. For more information on configuring TTS by adding paramters to this string, see Text-to-Speech Tips and Topics from Inventive Labs support.

String of Path and File Name
This specifies the file for the wave output. See remarks below about file format.

String
Description: This is the voice to be used in speaking the string into the file. Many vendors provide a whole range of voices to use, including male, female and different accents. The voices available to you are installed on the Voice Elements server. There are some low quality voices included in different versions of Windows for testing, but for production you may need to install one you prefer. For help finding out what voices you have, see How do I find what voices are available? from Inventive Labs support.
member.exception: Thrown when the file or text string are null or a file access exception occurs.
member.remarks:
Output File Format
The output file will usually be formatted as 8 kHz 8 bit mu-law wave file. Voice Elements uses native G.711 which determines the format. This is the codec used at the transport level for SIP, T1's and PRI's. This allows files to be played without any conversion overhead.
For more information on TTS settings on the server, see TTS Settings on Voice Elements Server from Inventive Labs support.
member.seealso: TTS Settings on Voice Elements Server

member.name: E:VoiceElements.Client.TelephonyServer.NewCall
member.summary: Fires when there is a new inbound call sent from the Voice Elements Server.
member.remarks:
You Must Register DNIS's to Receive Calls
Before the Voice Elements Server that handles telephony resources will send new calls to your application and fire this event, you must Register DNIS(s) with the Voice Elements Server. If this is not done, the server will not raise New Call Events. For more information about DNIS, see What's a DNIS?
Threading and Best Practices
Voice Elements handles creation of a thread behind the scenes before calling this event. You can spend the entire length of the call in this event, therefore there is no need to quickly exit. The simplest approach to designing a simple inbound application is to create a inbound script class and call that class from this event.
Define your New Call Event in your Start Up Code
Put something like this in your startup code: s_TelephonyServer.NewCall += new VoiceElements.Client.NewCall(s_TelephonyServer_NewCall); Determine the entry point of your application and decide where you would like to begin receiving these events. You may make this before or after you Register DNIS(s), since the server will not even try to raise events until the registration is done.
Subscribe to Disconnected Events
You should always subscribe to Disconnect Events (aka Hang Ups) immediately upon getting a New Call event. Always do this unless you explicitly have a reason not to do so. The following code line will do this subscription (C#): e.ChannelResource.Disconnected += new Disconnected(ChannelResource_Disconnected); Determine the entry point of your application and decide where you would like to begin receiving these events. You may make this before or after you Register DNIS(s), since the server will not even try to raise events until the registration is done.
member.returns: This event comes along with a New Call Argument Object, which contains a reference to the Channel Resource that has been assigned for the duration of the new call. You will use this object along with the Voice Resource for all Plays, Get Responses and other voice functions. To access the Voice Resource, you will find a reference in the Voice Resource Property of the Channel Resource in the NewCallEventArgs.
member.seealso: Registering DNIS's to Receive Inbound Calls

member.name: T:VoiceElements.Client.NewCall
member.summary: A delegate for the event that is fired when a new call arrives from the Voice Elements Server.
member.param: This is a reference to the object that has sent the New Call Event.

This is a reference to the New Call Event Args object. When receiving a new call, this is most useful for retrieving the Channel Resource and the Voice Resource, which are used for all voice processing/telephony functions for the call.
member.remarks:
Handling Inbound Call Basics
To begin learning about how to handle inbound calls, start by reading about the New Call Event.

member.name: T:VoiceElements.Client.NewCallEventArgs
member.summary: The event arguments that are supplied with a new call event including a reference to the assigned Channel Resource.
member.remarks:
Using the Arguments
The event passes along "e" as a reference to an instance of this class with the New Call Event. When receiving a new call, this is most useful for retrieving the Channel Resource and the Voice Resource, which are used for all voice processing/telephony functions for the call. You will use this object along with the Voice Resource for all Plays, Get Responses and other voice functions. To access the Voice Resource, you will find a reference in the Voice Resource Property of the Channel Resource in the NewCallEventArgs.
Getting Started: Inbound Calls
To begin learning about how to handle inbound calls, start by reading about the New Call Event.

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.NewCallEventArgs.#ctor(VoiceElements.Client.ChannelResource)
member.summary: Constructor for new call event arguments which include a reference to the Channel Resource assigned by the server.
member.param: When receiving a new call, this is a reference to the Channel Resource assigned by the Voice Elements Server and will therefore contain a reference within to the Voice Resource, which together with the Channel Resource are used for all voice processing/telephony functions for the call.
member.remarks:
Handling Inbound Call Basics
To begin learning about how to handle inbound calls, start by reading about the New Call Event.

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.NewCallEventArgs.ChannelResource
member.summary: The channel resource that encapsulates the call that is being offered by the server.
member.remarks:
Using the Channel Resource
When receiving a new call, use this Channel Resource to retrieve the associated Voice Resource, which are both used for all voice processing/telephony functions for the call, including Plays, Get Responses and other voice functions.
Getting Started: Inbound Calls
To begin learning about how to handle inbound calls, start by reading about the New Call Event.

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.NewCallEventArgs.Cancel
member.summary: Informs server to drop the incoming call. Leave false to take the call.
member.remarks:
Setting to True: Implications
If you set this to true, the New Call will be dropped immediately after you receive the New Call Event. It is not normal behavior unless you want your application to expicitly reject inbound calls.
Getting Started: Inbound Calls
To begin learning about how to handle inbound calls, start by reading about the New Call Event.

member.name: E:VoiceElements.Client.ChannelResource.NewCall
member.summary: Fires when there is a new inbound call sent from the Voice Elements Server.
member.remarks:
You Must Register DNIS's to Receive Calls
Before the Voice Elements Server that handles telephony resources will send new calls to your application and fire this event, you must Register DNIS(s) with the Voice Elements Server. If this is not done, the server will not raise New Call Events. For more information about DNIS, see What's a DNIS?
Threading and Best Practices
Voice Elements handles creation of a thread behind the scenes before calling this event. You can spend the entire length of the call in this event, therefore there is no need to quickly exit. The simplest approach to designing a simple inbound application is to create a inbound script class and call that class from this event.
Define your New Call Event in your Start Up Code
Put something like this in your startup code: s_TelephonyServer.NewCall += new VoiceElements.Client.NewCall(s_TelephonyServer_NewCall); Determine the entry point of your application and decide where you would like to begin receiving these events. You may make this before or after you Register DNIS(s), since the server will not even try to raise events until the registration is done.
Subscribe to Disconnected Events
You should always subscribe to Disconnect Events (aka Hang Ups) immediately upon getting a New Call event. Always do this unless you explicitly have a reason not to do so. The following code line will do this subscription (C#): e.ChannelResource.Disconnected += new Disconnected(ChannelResource_Disconnected); Determine the entry point of your application and decide where you would like to begin receiving these events. You may make this before or after you Register DNIS(s), since the server will not even try to raise events until the registration is done.
member.returns: This event comes along with a New Call Argument Object, which contains a reference to the Channel Resource that has been assigned for the duration of the new call. You will use this object along with the Voice Resource for all Plays, Get Responses and other voice functions. To access the Voice Resource, you will find a reference in the Voice Resource Property of the Channel Resource in the NewCallEventArgs.
member.seealso: Registering DNIS's to Receive Inbound Calls

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.GetResponse(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Waits for a DTMF Digit or voice response from the Speech Engine with parameters to change Voice Resource settings, including the termination digit.
member.param:
System.Int32
Description: The maximum number of digits to receive from the caller and return from the digit buffer. For more information, see

System.Int32
Description: The maximum time in seconds to wait for a response. For more information, see

System.String
Description: The termination digit. This digit, like a pound sign (#) would stop the response from waiting for more digits in a string. This is expecially helpful when getting a variable length or long string of input from a caller. For more information, see .
member.remarks:
This overloaded method allows you to temporarily override the current properties for MaximumDigits, MaximumTime and TerminationDigits for just this specific 'Get'.
Voice Resource Porperties vs GetResponse Override
This overload is designed to override settings that you may make through properties of the voice resource (VR). It is a consideration of style and your requirements of using the properties, which remain set or whether you would like to specify the paramters for just on call to GetResponse. These parameters include:
The maximum number of digits that willbe accepted from the caller.
The number of seconds to wait for the entire expected string of digits to be received.
This digit, like a pound sign (#) would stop the response from waiting for more digits in a string.

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.GetResponse(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits for a DTMF Digit or voice response from the Speech Engine with parameters to change Voice Resource settings, including specifying the timeout between digits in a string.
member.param:
System.Int32
Description: The maximum number of digits to receive from the caller and return from the digit buffer. For more information, see

System.Int32
Description: The maximum time in seconds to wait for a response. For more information, see

System.String
Description: The termination digit. This digit, like a pound sign (#) would stop the response from waiting for more digits in a string. This is expecially helpful when getting a variable length or long string of input from a caller. For more information, see .

System.Int32
Description: This is the number of seconds between digits in a string that will cause GetReponse to terminate and cosider the input of the string complete. This can typically be used to allow the input of a long string to terminate without requiring the caller to hit # or another termination digit. For more information, see .
member.remarks:
This overloaded method allows you to temporarily override the current properties for MaximumDigits, MaximumTime, TerminationDigits and InterDigitTimeout for just this specific 'Get'.
Voice Resource Porperties vs GetResponse Override
This overload is designed to override settings that you may make through properties of the voice resource (VR). It is a consideration of style and your requirements of using the properties, which remain set or whether you would like to specify the paramters for just on call to GetResponse. These parameters include:
The maximum number of digits that willbe accepted from the caller.
The number of seconds to wait for the entire expected string of digits to be received.
This digit, like a pound sign (#) would stop the response from waiting for more digits in a string.
This is the number of seconds between digits in a string that will cause GetReponse to terminate and consider the input of the string complete.

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.GetResponse(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits for a DTMF Digit or voice response from the Speech Engine with parameters to change Voice Resource settings, including specifically clearing the digit buffer.
member.param:
System.Int32
Description: The maximum number of digits to receive from the caller and return from the digit buffer. For more information, see

System.Int32
Description: The maximum time in seconds to wait for a response. For more information, see

System.String
Description: The termination digit. This digit, like a pound sign (#) would stop the response from waiting for more digits in a string. This is expecially helpful when getting a variable length or long string of input from a caller. For more information, see .

System.Int32
Description: This is the number of seconds between digits in a string that will cause GetReponse to terminate and consider the input of the string complete. This can typically be used to allow the input of a long string to terminate without requiring the caller to hit # or another termination digit. For more information, see .

System.Boolean
Description: Indicates whether or not to clear the digit buffer before beginnning the wait. For more information, see .
member.remarks:
This overloaded method allows you to temporarily override the current properties for MaximumDigits, MaximumTime, TerminationDigits and ClearDigitBuffer for just this specific 'Get'.
Voice Resource Porperties vs GetResponse Override
This overload, by having the most parameters is designed to override settings that you may make through properties of the voice resource (VR). It is a consideration of style and your requirements of using the properties, which remain set or whether you would like to specify the paramters for just on call to GetResponse. These parameters include:
The maximum number of digits that willbe accepted from the caller.
The number of seconds to wait for the entire expected string of digits to be received.
This digit, like a pound sign (#) would stop the response from waiting for more digits in a string.
This is the number of seconds between digits in a string that will cause GetReponse to terminate and consider the input of the string complete.
If set to true, digits in the buffer will be purged before the wait for response begins.

member.name: M:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.GetResponse
member.summary: Waits for a DTMF Digit or voice response from the Speech Engine using all current settings for the Voice Resource, and therefore has no parameters.
member.remarks:
This method does not set any of the required properties. Whatever has been set in the VR properties will be used to determine the behavior of the GetResponse call. See sample code below.
Voice Resource Properties and Overloads
This method has 3 overloads allowing you to set specific properties to control behavior. If you choose to use this method and not one of the overloads, keep in mind that you have set the properties before calling GetResponse. Consider GetResponse Overloads before implementing. The relevant properties you will need to set include:
The maximum number of digits that willbe accepted from the caller.
The number of seconds to wait for the entire expected string of digits to be received.
This digit, like a pound sign (#) would stop the response from waiting for more digits in a string.
This is the number of seconds between digits in a string that will cause GetReponse to terminate and consider the input of the string complete.
If set to true, digits in the buffer will be purged before the wait for response begins.

member.summary: Sets the voice resource to play a short beep before it begins recording.

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionFrequencyRangeLowHz
member.summary: The lowest frequency the beep detector will attempt to isolate. Default 600Hz.

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionFrequencyRangeHighHz
member.summary: The highest frequency the beep detector will attempt to isolate. Default 1800Hz.

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionPercentOfEnergy
member.summary: The percentage of energy that is contained within the frequency bin as compared to the overall energy. Default 0.90f

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionMinimumRequiredDb
member.summary: The minimum required energy in decibels for a packet to be examined. Default -38.0f Raising this value will eliminate quieter tones.

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionTimeOnToTriggerMs
member.summary: This is the total time the frequency must be registered before the system qualifies it as a beep. Default 200ms

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionMaximumTimeMs
member.summary: This is the maximum time the system will listen for a beep. Beep detection will stop after this interval. Default = 60000ms

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionDebouncerOn
member.summary: This is the required number of samples (each 10ms) that are required for the tone to be considered "on". Default = 4 samples

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionDebouncerOff
member.summary: This is the required number of samples (each 10ms) that are required for the tone to be considered "off". Default = 4 samples

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionToneOnEnergyDeviationDb
member.summary: The allowable deviation of the tone's loudness in decibels. If the tone starts at -15db it must stay at this level +/- this value. The default is 2.0 db.

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionToneOnFrequencyDeviation
member.summary: The allowable deviation of the tone's frequency in hertz. If the tone starts at 600hz it must stay at this frequency +/- this value. The default is 25 Hz.

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionShortToneMs
member.summary: The length of the shortest tone you wish to detect. For shorter tones, the tone must be immediately followed by silence. The default is 120ms.

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionShortToneSilenceTriggerMs
member.summary: The amount of required silence after a short tone goes to silence. The default is 40ms.

member.name: P:VoiceElements.Client.VoiceResource.BeepDetectionMetaData
member.summary: When the server is recording beep detection, this allows you to add additional information to the filename that is create. Be sure to only use characters that are permissable within filenames.
